column9: but it can be done. It still fits perfectly in my pocket or purse so that has been a non issue and I'm actually liking the larger screen size. It definitely enhances FaceTime.I also upgraded from 16gb on my 5s to 64gb on the 6 because I got sick of running out of room. If you make the choice to buy the 6
column10: go with at least the 64gb of storage as it's not a huge price difference but a LOT more storage.It also synced right up with my iPad so if I'm reading or using my tab I can decline or answer calls and reply to texts from my tab as well as my phone.If you are getting gold or silver or whatever because you like the color of the phone
column11: I suggest getting a Moshi case to match your phone. They have cases here on Amazon by Moshi that will protect your iPhone 6 without taking away from the color.Other than the screen size and the storage I upgraded
column12: there's not a big difference between this and the 5s
column13: but even then I do love the new design. Now if you're upgrading from just a 4 or regular 5
column14: you'll love the Touch ID and other perks. If you're an iPhone lover
column15: this one will not disappoint. If you use Android
column16: this phone may be the one that converts you to the iPhone. I have two family members who were die hard Samsung fans and they are now changing to the iPhone 6 after seeing mine.

Title: This phone is pretty easy to use but
Author: Becky LeBeau
Review: This phone is pretty easy to use but...these are the issues I have with it. It doesn't have enough space. Can't have many pictures or apps. I have to keep deleting things or the camera doesn't work. Every time I upgrade it downloads another app that I don't want or need and I can't delete it. I don't have an apple watch! Why would I need the app? Also when I charge the phone in any car the radio gets fuzzy. It also uses data when I'm connected to WIFI! I'm a new mother of twins. I sometimes don't get out of the house for days at a time but I'm getting text messages saying "you have used 75% of your data". How? Verizon blames Apple. They say the phone uses data even if you are connected to WIFI. I only work the weekends! I thought 3 GB would be enough since I'm connected to WIFI 5 out of 7 days. guess not!Love my new iPhone

Title: Nothing Innovative Here Folks
Author: BUT...
column5: I LOVE THIS PHONE!So Ill break it down for you guys. Im not the biggest Apple fan in the world. I do not own anything other than an iPhone. But I have been buying iPhones for 6 plus years (no pun intended). I've been a huge fan of the super user friendly iOS that they have on them. The phones have a lot of limitations. But for a phone
column6: I would never complain. I will say the same thing I tell everyone who asks about iPhones and iPads and what have you
column7: "The iPhone is a great phone
column8: but if you want a tablet
column9: go android." The android tablets defeat the iPad in every way I could possible imagine. Yet
column10: I digress.Now onto the iPhone 6 itself. I purchased the space grey model with the 128gb hard drive. The very first thing I noticed with this phone was the screen. I wont go into the specifics of pixel density. The iPhone 6 does not have the highest. But the particular screen they used is what is called 5k (basically 4k but Apples name for it) and it just looks beautiful. The clarity it boasts puts not only previous iPhones
column11: but other past phones to shame. Like it should right? Its a brand new phone. It should be a lot more innovative than any phone that came before it
column12: right? Well
column13: my answer to that is no
column14: it doesnt. Apple took what we loved of the iPhone and just reused it in this phone. They improved a lot of the phones features
column15: but once again
column16: there is nothing that this phone offers that you could not find in other phones on the market today. But Im still loyal to the iPhone for its incredibly easy to use interface.Now the next thing that blew my mind with this phone is the camera and video recorder. I go to concerts a lot. And I love getting pictures of the bands while they are in action. I also love getting videos of my favorite songs so I can relieve those moments. Ive recorded a lot of videos with previous phones and the audio/video quality is just terrible. Until I got this phone. The camera has a new software added to it to allow it to keep focused much better than the previous phones. The same software is used in one of the newer Samsung phones as well
column17: so once again
column18: nothing new to the table. So when me and my friend are at a Blue Oyster Cult concert
column19: we decided to see who's phone recorded better audio/video. He was using the Samsung Galaxy 5. His video was the same if not slightly better than mine. He could also zoom in much closer than I was able too. However
column20: the audio on my videos kicked his phones butt up and down that stage. Anytime the drums would
column21: be it bass pedal or cymbal
column22: his phones audio would just clip. Meanwhile
column23: my iPhone takes those louder noises in stride and produced the best video I've ever managed to record on a phone. Also
column24: just to add a bit more
column25: there was a short film shot entirely with an iPhone 6. Its a FPS romance film about two lovers living their day to day life in New York I do believe. I watched the trailer they had on Youtube for it a while back and the quality was really good. So kudos iPhone for filming a movie!They added some new apps to the iPhone when this phone came out. Though I do believe you can get those apps on the previous incarnations of the iPhone. The biggest thing Apple has been bragging about however is Apple Pay. Unlucky for me
column26: I live in a smaller city that hasnt quite adapted to these "new fangled ways" of getting into dept
column27: I mean shopping. So I havent gotten to try Apple Pay. Maybe one day soon though.So all in all guys
column28: I love my iPhone 6. This phone however does not offer something that you couldnt find in another phone
column29: except maybe the stupid high amount of memory you can get now. And for someone like me who loves having an easy to use interface and a bunch of memory (my phone is my iPod. Its just more convenient) then this phone would be a damn good choice. Apple could have put more features and made the phone much more unique
column30: but I was happy with the changes they've made since the iPhone 5 and I just hope the iPhone 7 will give us features on our phones we never knew possible. Happy shopping fellows.

column14: and I was switching cell phone companies anyway) to the iPhone 6 64GB phone (not the "plus version" - too big for my needs).  I AM SWITCHING BACK to an ANDROID.  I wanted to be fair and give it 30 days
column15: which I think should be enough time to test a lot of the basic features I would use every day.  I have been on this iPhone 6 10-12 hours a day for the past 30 days Emailing
column16: texting
column17: calling
column18: Internet searching
column19: photo-taking
column20: etc.  My conclusion: for a business owner
column21: the Android is MUCH better for the following reasons (and these are only the ones I've discovered in the past 30 days):1. On the Android
column22: I was able to forward to my assistant
column23: via text
column24: any voicemails I didn't need to handle and text her a message saying "Could you please handle this?".  You can’t do this on the iPhone 6.  You can't even do it via Email unless you download an app.  After downloading this app and taking over an hour to set it up
column25: I discovered that
column26: when calling other people
column27: the caller ID now does not show MY name or MY phone number.  It shows some other phone #
column28: which may cause a client not to answer my call.  Also
column29: building a brand is important to a business
column30: and this caller ID issue is not good for branding.  So
column31: I either have to live without forwarding voicemail messages (which is a huge time saver!!) or keep it and have some random phone number and name show up when I call others.  In the end
column32: the functionality should just BE THERE in the first place and be easy to figure out like it was on the Droid.2. You cannot set up a default signature for a text.  In other words
column33: with each text
column34: on the Android
column35: my message was followed by my name and my website.  Again - a great branding thing because my friends
column36: family and business associates are reminded of what I do without me being in their face about it
column37: but also
column38: if a new client or prospect doesn’t have my contact info/phone number saved into their phone yet
column39: this lets them know who is texting them and they might respond more quickly.  In addition
column40: they might also consider visiting my website after seeing my default signature (what business doesn't want that?!).  I found out that you can set up a shortcut on the iPhone to MANUALLY add it at the end of each text
column41: but I can’t remember to do it because I am BUSY and I don't think I should have to remember to do it.  It should just BE there.  Therefore
column42: this is brand identity that I have lost with the iPhone.3. You cannot search the Internet when you're on an iPhone 6.  You CAN do this on the Droid.  I OFTEN search for things on the Internet while on the phone when a client has a question or one of my team members calls me and needs something.4. The iPhone 6 camera is NOT very good.  Photos are a core part of my business (and also my personal life) and the clarity of the photos on the iPhone 6 are not as good as my OLD Droid.  I thought maybe I could change the default size on the camera menu to a larger size (as you can do on the Droid) to improve the quality
column43: but no iPhone user has been able to tell me how and I can't find it on the menus or the Internet.  To explain
column44: when I take a photo and then zoom in on the photo
column45: it is blurry.  Yes
column46: BLURRY.  I previously had a Galaxy S3 (a pretty "old" phone) and you could zoom in on any object and the clarity would be fantastic when you zoomed in on the captured image.  As an example
column47: when letters were too tiny on labels
column48: I used to use the camera on that S3 phone to take a photo of the label and then I would zoom in I would be able to read it.  Can't do this with the iPhone 6.  With photos of people
column49: it's the same thing.  What's up with this?  The other reviews I've read show that its clarity is not as good.  I really wish I'd done my research before just believing all the iPhone fans out there.  Apparently
column50: they don’t know what they don’t have.5. The texting program is not intuitive.  On the Droid
column51: it was very smart and intuitive.  It got used to words you used a lot and would automatically bring them up as default options and even correct your grammar very well.  The iPhone does not do this
column52: even if I've typed the same word 200 times in 30 days (like my daughter's name
column53: for instance).  The talk-to-text is also less accurate.  The Droid gets more and more accurate as it learns your speech patterns and pronunciations.  Also
column55: tapping and holding where the incorrect spelling is and dragging it is much less efficient and requires more accuracy on the iPhone and also sometimes takes 3-4 attempts to even get it to recognize where I'm tapping.  It takes me 3x as long to type a text.  Not good in my business.  Also
column56: the swipe-texting feature is delivered with the Droid – and I love this feature.  When I can’t voice-to-text because I’m in a quiet place
column57: it helps me text more quickly that tapping the letters on the keyboard.  You apparently have to download the swipe-texting function for the iPhone  but I'm not even going to bother since I've wasted too much time trying to configure the phone and adapt to IT versus IT adapting to MY needs.  It's just too frustrating and time-consuming to download apps to fix things that should be there by default like the Droid.6. Working the iPhone 6 with one hand is much more difficult due to where the menu selections are.  It was much easier to use the Droid when only having one hand free.I was willing to cough up the exorbitant cost of the iPhone if it would save me time and if it was a much better experience
column58: since I don't have a lot of time at this stage of my business and in many cases
column59: “you get what you pay for”.  If I'm paying almost $800 for a phone (I don’t like contracts)
column60: I expect the same or better than the Droid
column61: as all "die hard" iPhone users say it is.  What I am finding is that most iPhone users have only ever BEEN iPhone users and that they don't know what functionality they're not getting because they have always had an iPhone.  I wanted to enter into it with an open mind and judge it based on my experience and my needs.  Yes
column62: there are probably things about the iPhone that are better than a Droid (not sure what yet)
column63: but for a business person whose priority is BRANDING
column64: and considering the value for the money
column65: this phone is definitely not for me.Again - PLEASE feel free to correct me if I'm wrong
column67: I have given up on finding answers to these issues.  I need to get back to building and BRANDING my business now...  I'm researching Android phone options now
column68: but reviews and articles are pointing to the new Galaxy S6 or the Galaxy  Note 4 as the best phones for BUSINESS.  I don't care about the battery not being removable on the Galaxy S6 or that there is no Micro SD card slot (I'm buying a 64 GB version).  My fingers are crossed that I can get back on track with my business very soon after I switch back.

Title: I LIST THE IMPROVED FEATURES OVER THE 5.
Author: Harkanwar Anand
Review: I don't agree with critics who say Apple hasn't made significant improvements from the iPhone 5. Everyone who is reading this review has probably owned an iPhone 5 and some own even older models. There are a few improvements since say the iPhone 5 so I wanted to help the audience that has the iPhone 5 (not saying I exclude others)Here are the major improvements since the iPhone 5
column6: there is more detail
column7: almost takes a photo in the worst ever lit room
column8: very sharp
column9: excellent photos
column10: the macro could be a little better but you can download several applications to counter the macro recognition system. Older iPhone 5 now looks grainy.b) CALL QUALITY - Much louder on speaker
column11: better earphone speaker than before. The iPhone 5 was very good but when I hold it right next to the iPhone 6
column12: the difference is substantial.c) SPEAKER - Much louder
column13: clearer
column14: still wouldn't replace my JBL bluetooth but still good enough. Much clearer whether on phone call or while playing music. You almost never ever keep it on 100% volume cause its rudely loud otherwise. I have compared this with my wife's HTC one m8 and it is almost as loud as the boom speaker but we all know HTC has the best speaker.d) BUILD QUALITY - For the first month
column15: I kind of regretted getting the 6 because it is so much bigger and the one handed operation was useless. I almost never use reachability. The 6 is much more slippery than the iPhone 5 and using without a case is not even an option. So I would say despite the changes
column16: being lighter
column17: i miss the 5's ease of use and builde) TOUCH ID - DOn't think it makes a difference? You are wrong. It is convenient if not flawless in execution.f) Display - The brightness and pixel density has improved which ideally means you will find watching videos much better. Owing to a better graphics procesor the iPhone 6 is better for reading
column18: viewing videos.g) iOS 8 is definitely optimised for iPhone 6. I'm sorry but the Iphone 5 was running the iOS 8 really slow. I really hated it. I was almost strong armed into purchasing the iPhone 6 but overall I can't say I am not satisfied.Thank God for the 128GB. I no longer have to worry about keeping Pearl Jam's discography on my iPhone.h) OTHERS - It can charge faster if you use the iPad Air adapter
column19: the battery life is much much better and lasts me about 18 hours which is satisfactory
column20: I read this more often for reading because iBooks is so much fun on this
column21: Apple Pay doesnt work where I live (we avoid using card and love CASH despite it being slimy)

Title: The perspective from switching to iphone from android
Author: Amircat1
Review: So I made the switch from using Android to the iPhone back in October
column5: and I've been using the iPhone 6 for the past few months now and can give a detailed review on what it's like to switch over. Before this switch
column6: I've used the Samsung Galaxy S2 (first smartphone ever!) and also the Nexus 4. Since I'm a tech enthusiast
column7: I'm well versed and have played around with many other Android devices
column8: including all the big names
column9: Galaxy S5
column10: HTC One M8 and M7
column11: One Plus One
column12: and so on. Here are my thoughts:Things that the iPhone does really well (both hardware and software-wise):1. Camera. The behind the scene software for digitally capturing an image is definitely the strongest sell for the iPhone. Other than the S5 and Note 4
column13: no smartphone really comes close to having the same kind of image quality (no matter the megapixels) compared to the iPhone. This was one of the reasons for me to switch over since I've started to dabble with photography and wanted a really good camera in my smartphone. (Side note
column14: if you read a lot of tech blogs
column15: there is a notion that in the near future our smartphones won't accurately describe our devices anymore since making a phone call is probably one of the least commonly used features on a smartphone when you look at any average user. Cameras
column16: social media
column17: emails all take a higher usage rate than making a call... really interesting
column18: but anyway
column19: back to the review).2. Reliability. There have been maybe 2 or 3 times when my phone crashed and would have to be restarted
column20: mostly due to playing some game that was not written very well for the iOS devices. On Android devices
column21: I've experienced a lot more crashes
column22: and that may be due to the fact that so many apps haven't figured out the best way to optimize the app for each individual phone due to the fragmentation problems or something else. Either way
column23: I feel like the iOS environment and hardware is more reliable in my everyday use.3. Fingerprint sensor. Once you've used it
column24: you won't go back. The S5 is not that close yet in terms of usability with their sensor. The one in the iPhone 6 works really well. I definitely have found myself using my phone more because of how easy it is to unlock and install apps.4. Control of apps. This is an interesting point. In general
column25: you get way more control over how to use and how to integrate your apps on Android than iOS. But in iOS
column26: it's really interesting that you can control the kind of notification that gets sent to your phone
column28: location requirement
column29: and access to certain things like photos and camera. In Android
column30: you can do all of this as well
column31: but sometimes for a lot of apps you have to have root access.5. Double tap to bring down the row of apps. I can't believe no one has thought of this before. A lot of Android phones have gigantic screens
column32: but no one has really figured out how to best get the users to interact with that. You can tap the home button twice on the iPhone to bring down the top few rows of the apps so that you can access them in one hand use.Here are the things that I miss on Android:1. Full integration of almost any apps and control of default apps. I can set default apps on Android whereas Apple does not allow that. I can open up photos and upload them to Dropbox or any other app that I choose to
column33: whereas Apple doesn't allow uploading to Dropbox via the Photos app (you have to open up Dropbox
column34: then select upload and then go to Photos from there).2. Better email. In the mail app for Android
column35: you can attach almost any file on the phone. You can't do that on Apple. You can't even attach a single file. You have to share a file as an email. So
column36: forget about replying an email with an attachment. This is pretty annoying.3. Productivity is better on Android. If you are a big dropbox user
column37: you probably know and love Dropsync on Android (seriously
column38: best 5 bucks spent on any app). You can have an app that syncs and download any material from Dropbox onto your Android and then sync it back up when changes are detected. It's so seamless. Apple does NOT allow that (mainly because they don't allow background apps from accessing the hard drive
column39: or something along those lines). So you have to download the file you are interested in manually from the Dropbox app. It just slows you down a lot
column40: especially if you get to a part of a building where there is weak signal for wifi or cellular data.4. Notifications are way better. Why can't Apple make one button that clears all of your notifications? You have to individually close each app's own notification. I pretty much leave my notification screen untouched.5. Some other things that many already know: Google Now is way better/useful than Siri. Material design looks awesome! Way better widgets and the fact that you can have widgets!! Oh
column41: and you can swipe right on the home screen on Android and that brings another screen from the left side... can't do that on iOS
column42: the home page is set to be the left most one. More customization and etc.Conclusion:Overall
column43: I think the iPhone is a fine device to use and you probably won't regret investing in one. The customer service from Apple is top notch
column44: even if their parts cost an arm and leg. I think that
column45: and I hate to say this because it's going to sound like every blog writer out there
column46: the choice really does come down to personal preference and what you use the phone for. So
column47: I've broken down my recommendation based on user case scenarios:If you are user type...Workaholic
column48: Students: Android will be the best option unless your company/job dictates that you use an iPhone. The integration with all the apps and the feature with dropbox is just so important to anyone who works on their phones and other mobile devices. I would either get a pure Google device (N5 or N6
column49: I like smaller phones... so N5 is up there) or a Google Edition device
column50: or the Moto X. Samsung and HTC are also good choices but updates may be slow. One Plus One is actually pretty cool. They are not the best when it comes to customer service since they're a small company filling huge demand
column52: the device is solid and definitely a work horse.Medical and Science community: iPhone. Unfortunately
column53: most of the med and science people rely on Apple products
column54: and a lot of new apps still come to iOS first or are better updated and designed on iOS.Recreational
column55: use a phone as a communication device and for fun: iPhone. The camera and social apps are fun to use on the iPhone.For older folks: This is a split. If you've used Apple products before
column56: then iOS will be easy to learn. Android phones have gotten a LOT easier to use thanks to a big push from Google dealing with not only the UI from a software perspective but also from a design perspective. It is more intuitive than it used to be.Photographer
column58: foodie: iPhone 6 still has the best selection of apps and arguably the best camera. Samsung's camera is great
column59: but the company is known to really bog down their stellar devices with bloatware that ruins or significantly slows down your phone after 1 year of use. I love the HTC ONE in design
column60: but their gamble on the cameras have not paid off for their customers or themselves.So was this the right switch for me? As I'm learning more about the iPhone and iOS
column61: I've realized that when the two year is over or whenever this phone dies on me
column62: I'll most likely switch back to Android. While I think I've been thoroughly spoiled by the fingerprint sensor
column63: the productivity that I enjoyed on Android just doesn't replicate itself here on the iPhone. Maybe it's not meant to be a super productive machine
column64: but I guess my main point is that I'd like to have that option available when I need it.Another side note: Most of the shortfalls of either Android and iOS can be bypassed via means of rooting
column66: and jailbreaking (in the case of iOS). And I do understand that a lot of people enjoy doing this and can get their phones to work fantastically well. I used to do a lot of customization and go through ROMs once every three days on my Android devices
column67: but I've come to realize that I'd rather spend that time using the device than customizing it. So
column69: I just want my devices to work right out of the box. The little details like a great camera
column71: and the ability to have my dropbox synced on the go and a good notification system should all be there when I turn on my phone.Summary and TL; DR:So there you have it. An Android user's thoughts on using the iPhone 6. Do I have regrets switching over? After using my friend's One Plus One and seeing Material Design on my old N4
column72: I definitely regret it. But for now
column74: even if there are occasional frustration points. If you are an Android user
column75: please consider all these points and google similar stories before switching.Also
column76: I'm one of those workaholics and forever in search of super productivity
column77: hence my review that I'd like to go back to Android. However
column78: I know plenty of people who swear by their iPhones for productivity. If you are always connected and depend on a suite of iOS specific apps (including apps that are better designed or work better on iOS)
column79: then chances are you love the iPhone. There are plenty of things to like and love about either OS. It really does come down to personal preference.***UPDATE 2/9/15: I got to try the new Outlook 2015 app by Microsoft
column80: and it has alleviated a lot of the email/attachment issues that I have mentioned above. It allows you to sign into your Exchange
column81: Outlook accounts as well as your Gmail
column83: and iCloud emails. You can also integrate your OneDrive
column86: and that's where the magic begins. Once integrated
column87: you can attach any file located in those drives
column88: which is great! You can also attach files that are attached in emails that are already in your inbox! And
column89: you can now reply an email with the option of attaching a file. Finally
column90: you can decide if you want to open up links from emails in Safari or another browser installed on your phone (so
column91: you are no longer bound by default Apple apps). This is a huge step forward
column92: and it's from Microsoft (a pleasant surprise). ***This app has really improved my productivity needs
column93: since when considering the iPhone we have to take into account the hardware and the software/app ecosystem
column94: i think this makes sense to bump up the rating to 4/5. There are still kinks when switching over if you are used to productive flexibility on Android phones
column95: but right now the 3rd party apps are getting better and better at work-arounds.

In January I was at Best Buy browsing at the cellphones to see what was out there.  I was shocked to see that what I had been paying for that little talk/text phone through Sprint that I could have had unlimited talk/text/data for the same price.  Sprint has changed their individual plans to be more affordable.  Just about everyone in my family has an iPhone so I thought

Title: Bugs

column6: I have had so many problems with this phone that I felt obligated to write a review. I don't know what exactly happened here with apple but this product just has problems. Before anyone starts accusing me of being an Android fan  I want to say that I actually really like iphone over android
column7: I have had both in the past and I prefer iOS when it works properly.So here is my user experience with this phone
column8: I received this phone a couple months ago
column9: and when I initially got it it worked great
column10: everything was smooth
column11: calls were coming through fine
column12: I liked the design of the phone
column13: I thought it was perfect. About 2 weeks after I received the phone
column14: there was a new iOS update that came out
column15: so I went ahead and downloaded the new update. That is the point that all my problems started. After the update there were two main problems
column16: one was that text messages would never come through for many of my contacts
column17: I just never received them
column18: they said they sent them and I actually looked at the other persons phone and I never got what was sent to me. The other problem that I had was continuously getting dropped and failed calls
column19: I would make 3-4 calls to a person before I finally got it to ring
column20: and even than it would sometimes connect with a lot of static.I worked extensively with my phone carrier
column21: I called 7-8 times and performed all the same troubleshooting with every technician I spoke with
column22: each call was around 2 hours
column23: some were more
column24: so I probably spent close to 20 hours troubleshooting these issues
column25: I was able to get the phone to operate better by disabling iMessage which helped my texts and than by disabling voice over LTE and just having it be for data. This and I had to reset network settings on my phone
column26: reset the settings and content a couple times
column27: I also had several things that my phone carrier did for me
column28: including registering me to their network again. After all of this was said and done
column29: I greatly reduced the amount of dropped
column30: and failed phone calls and I also received all text messages coming to my phone from that point on. My phone carrier told me I should go to the store and get a new phone
column31: but I didn't because most of the problems were gone and it seemed to be working the way it shouldOk
column32: so issue resolved right? Well
column33: yes with that device
column34: what happened was I had to get a new iPhone
column35: so my iPhone was sitting in a case
column36: and it really wasn't even in my pocket or anything
column37: one day the colors on the bottom right of my screen got dimmer for some reason. So I brought it up to my phone carrier and they looked at it
column38: and they checked for water damage and this and that and said that the phone looks physically fine
column39: and that I would need to go to an apple store and get it replaced. I went to the Apple store and worked with technicians there
column40: they also confirmed what my phone provider said
column41: and were going to replace the screen only
column42: but after looking at my phone they said the button on the side was a little stiff so they said it would be best to replace the phone entirely
column43: well because I was already there and had all those issues in the past I thought my phone just might not have been made correctly and that I have a bad phone so I agreed and got the phone replaced with a brand new one.I don't know what exactly happened or what they did
column44: the phone was trying to get all of the apps downloaded again that I had on my last phone
column45: it was downloading and installing them for literally 2 days which I thought was really weird. The new phone seemed much better in regards to calls that I was having problems with
column46: but the phone would not open a lot of apps
column47: it would start opening and freeze
column48: than sometimes the screen would turn black and pressing the power button or the home screen would not illuminate your phone. Also holding the power button down when it did this did not do anything to the phone. I figured out a way around it by pressing the power and the home at the same time I think it restarts it and it goes through the loading process. However
column49: sometimes the wifi would also disconnect
column50: than I would go in and try to reconnect
column51: but I wouldn't be able to turn the wifi on through the settings.So I have had this iPhone 6 since late November
column52: it is now the End of Febuary
column53: Febuary 28th to be precise. That is a good 3 months to try out the phone
column55: and I am able to use it
column56: but there are all kinds of glitches that I mentioned above now
column57: related to the screen going out and wifi not connecting and apps not loading or freezing the phone. The problems are not consistant either
column58: so when the phone works it's great
column59: but I've had two of them now
column60: and in both cases I've had different intermittent problems and bugs come up in the last 3 months. Since I waited for a while to make a review I feel that I can really assess the phone.Most of the people on here give this phone a 5 star rating
column61: blindly rating it. This is not a 5 star phone. I had a iPhone 3GS in the past that I had no problems with at all
column62: than I got an HTC one which I had no real problems with it
column63: but as the device got old the hardware started going so it needed to be replaced and I got this phone now. I think iOS is a much better user interface than Android
column64: but since iOS 8 has come out it is far more buggy than android. The androids may not be as user friendly and might be slightly more complicated to use
column65: and may not get some of the apps or there may be delays or whatever
column67: the phones stayed on and you could make phone calls and get texts. So my opinion is that Apple really rushed this phone
column68: they did not put in the time or quality that they are known forRight now my phone seems to be working ok I guess
column69: but the reason I am giving it a one star is because:1. Quality: The amount of bugs and glitches in this device is not acceptable
column70: the iphone 6 and iphone 6 plus are the most expensive phones on the market right now
column71: customers are paying this amount because they are expecting a higher quality product and are willing to pay for it. When the phone has so many problems with it that it's useless at times
column72: and having problems even after you get a new device that says to me that the devices are not made well.2. Price: This is one of the most expensive phones on the market and Apple is overcharging for this phone
column73: I felt that I had to get a 64GB phone because it's 2015
column74: 16 GB would fill up immediately when you consider how large the apps are nowadays or how big the pictures are as well.3. Hardware: As mentioned above
column75: the entry point on this phone is 16GB
column76: I don't think that is acceptable for a premium phone at this point in time. Further
column77: there are real problems when it comes to multitasking because of the lack of memory
column78: this phone comes with only 1GB of RAM
column79: this was fine in the last generation but considering that they're supposed to be competing against Samsung when you compare other premium phones from competitors it's really unacceptable. The S5 by Samsung I would consider it to be the regular iPhone 6's main competitor
column80: it has 2GB of RAM but has been on the market for much longer than the iPhone 6. The Samsung Note 4 is the iPhone 6 plus's main competitor
column81: it came out roughly around the same time the iPhone 6 plus came out
column82: but it has 3 GB of RAM vs 1 GB of RAM
column83: anyone that multitasks or accesses heavily intensive applications is going to notice choppiness especially with future releases of their operating system like iOS 9 and 10 whenever they come out. Considering that an extra gig of RAM would have cost the company at most an extra dollar per model and you are paying hundreds of dollars to begin with this is not ok. Also when you go to the store and you want a 64 GB storage card it doesn't cost hundreds of dollars
column84: so the difference in price between the 16 and 64 GB version should not be $1004. Customer Service - As I mentioned I have been having a lot of problems with my phone
column85: and I tried getting a new phone through my cellphone provider. If you have similar problems with any other phone by any other brand they will replace your cellphone while it's under warranty right there at the providers store
column86: this is not the case with Apple products though

column89: some people live really far away from Apple stores and can't be without their phones so shipping isn't really an option. I don't think a company can act this way to their customers and this in my opinion even though I know it's minor compared to the other things I've mentioned is kinda a big deal for me

column111: I would have rated this phone a 4

column114: and the RAM issue because I don't think a premium phone should only have 1GB of ram and find that insulting to the customer

column119: otherwise I would have bought a free phone which I would expect to have some problems and be fine with it. The fact that this item has so many problems and is really promoted by every carrier as the best product that they carry is absurd.

Title: An Android User's Review of the iPhone 6: Read this if you are thinking of switching from Android!!!
Author: Jay
Review: So I made the switch from using Android to the iPhone back in October
column5: and I've been using the iPhone 6 for the past few months now and can give a detailed review on what it's like to switch over.  Before this switch
column6: I've used the Samsung Galaxy S2 (first smartphone ever!) and also the Nexus 4.  Since I'm a tech enthusiast
column7: I'm well versed and have played around with many other Android devices
column8: including all the big names
column9: Galaxy S5
column10: HTC One M8 and M7
column11: One Plus One
column12: and so on.  Here are my thoughts:Things that the iPhone does really well (both hardware and software-wise):1. Camera.  The behind the scene software for digitally capturing an image is definitely the strongest sell for the iPhone.  Other than the S5 and Note 4
column13: no smartphone really comes close to having the same kind of image quality (no matter the megapixels) compared to the iPhone.  This was one of the reasons for me to switch over since I've started to dabble with photography and wanted a really good camera in my smartphone.  (Side note
column14: if you read a lot of tech blogs
column15: there is a notion that in the near future our smartphones won't accurately describe our devices anymore since making a phone call is probably one of the least commonly used features on a smartphone when you look at any average user.  Cameras
column16: social media
column17: emails all take a higher usage rate than making a call... really interesting
column18: but anyway
column19: back to the review).2.  Reliability.  There have been maybe 2 or 3 times when my phone crashed and would have to be restarted
column20: mostly due to playing some game that was not written very well for the iOS devices.  On Android devices
column21: I've experienced a lot more crashes
column22: and that may be due to the fact that so many apps haven't figured out the best way to optimize the app for each individual phone due to the fragmentation problems or something else.  Either way
column23: I feel like the iOS environment and hardware is more reliable in my everyday use.3. Fingerprint sensor.  Once you've used it
column24: you won't go back.  The S5 is not that close yet in terms of usability with their sensor.  The one in the iPhone 6 works really well.  I definitely have found myself using my phone more because of how easy it is to unlock and install apps.4. Control of apps.  This is an interesting point.  In general
column25: you get way more control over how to use and how to integrate your apps on Android than iOS.  But in iOS
column26: it's really interesting that you can control the kind of notification that gets sent to your phone
column28: location requirement
column29: and access to certain things like photos and camera.  In Android
column30: you can do all of this as well
column31: but sometimes for a lot of apps you have to have root access.5.  Double tap to bring down the row of apps.  I can't believe no one has thought of this before.  A lot of Android phones have gigantic screens
column32: but no one has really figured out how to best get the users to interact with that.  You can tap the home button twice on the iPhone to bring down the top few rows of the apps so that you can access them in one hand use.Here are the things that I miss on Android:1. Full integration of almost any apps and control of default apps.  I can set default apps on Android whereas Apple does not allow that.  I can open up photos and upload them to Dropbox or any other app that I choose to
column33: whereas Apple doesn't allow uploading to Dropbox via the Photos app (you have to open up Dropbox
column34: then select upload and then go to Photos from there).2. Better email.  In the mail app for Android
column35: you can attach almost any file on the phone.  You can't do that on Apple.  You can't even attach a single file.  You have to share a file as an email.  So
column36: forget about replying an email with an attachment.  This is pretty annoying.3. Productivity is better on Android.  If you are a big dropbox user
column37: you probably know and love Dropsync on Android (seriously
column38: best 5 bucks spent on any app).  You can have an app that syncs and download any material from Dropbox onto your Android and then sync it back up when changes are detected.  It's so seamless.  Apple does NOT allow that (mainly because they don't allow background apps from accessing the hard drive
column39: or something along those lines).  So you have to download the file you are interested in manually from the Dropbox app.  It just slows you down a lot
column40: especially if you get to a part of a building where there is weak signal for wifi or cellular data.4. Notifications are way better.  Why can't Apple make one button that clears all of your notifications?  You have to individually close each app's own notification.  I pretty much leave my notification screen untouched.5.  Some other things that many already know: Google Now is way better/useful than Siri.  Material design looks awesome! Way better widgets and the fact that you can have widgets!! Oh
column41: and you can swipe right on the home screen on Android and that brings another screen from the left side... can't do that on iOS
column42: the home page is set to be the left most one.  More customization and etc.Conclusion:Overall
column43: I think the iPhone is a fine device to use and you probably won't regret investing in one.  The customer service from Apple is top notch
column44: even if their parts cost an arm and leg.  I think that
column45: and I hate to say this because it's going to sound like every blog writer out there
column46: the choice really does come down to personal preference and what you use the phone for.  So
column47: I've broken down my recommendation based on user case scenarios:If you are user type...Workaholic
column48: Students: Android will be the best option unless your company/job dictates that you use an iPhone.  The integration with all the apps and the feature with dropbox is just so important to anyone who works on their phones and other mobile devices.  I would either get a pure Google device (N5 or N6
column49: I like smaller phones... so N5 is up there) or a Google Edition device
column50: or the Moto X.  Samsung and HTC are also good choices but updates may be slow.  One Plus One is actually pretty cool.  They are not the best when it comes to customer service since they're a small company filling huge demand
column52: the device is solid and definitely a work horse.Medical and Science community: iPhone.  Unfortunately
column53: most of the med and science people rely on Apple products
column54: and a lot of new apps still come to iOS first or are better updated and designed on iOS.Recreational
column55: use a phone as a communication device and for fun:  iPhone.  The camera and social apps are fun to use on the iPhone.For older folks: This is a split.  If you've used Apple products before
column56: then iOS will be easy to learn.  Android phones have gotten a LOT easier to use thanks to a big push from Google dealing with not only the UI from a software perspective but also from a design perspective.  It is more intuitive than it used to be.Photographer
column58: foodie: iPhone 6 still has the best selection of apps and arguably the best camera.  Samsung's camera is great
column59: but the company is known to really bog down their stellar devices with bloatware that ruins or significantly slows down your phone after 1 year of use.  I love the HTC ONE in design
column60: but their gamble on the cameras have not paid off for their customers or themselves.So was this the right switch for me?  As I'm learning more about the iPhone and iOS
column61: I've realized that when the two year is over or whenever this phone dies on me
column62: I'll most likely switch back to Android.  While I think I've been thoroughly spoiled by the fingerprint sensor
column63: the productivity that I enjoyed on Android just doesn't replicate itself here on the iPhone.  Maybe it's not meant to be a super productive machine
column64: but I guess my main point is that I'd like to have that option available when I need it.Another side note:  Most of the shortfalls of either Android and iOS can be bypassed via means of rooting
column66: and jailbreaking (in the case of iOS).  And I do understand that a lot of people enjoy doing this and can get their phones to work fantastically well.  I used to do a lot of customization and go through ROMs once every three days on my Android devices
column67: but I've come to realize that I'd rather spend that time using the device than customizing it.  So
column69: I just want my devices to work right out of the box.  The little details like a great camera
column71: and the ability to have my dropbox synced on the go and a good notification system should all be there when I turn on my phone.Summary and TL; DR:So there you have it.  An Android user's thoughts on using the iPhone 6.  Do I have regrets switching over?  After using my friend's One Plus One and seeing Material Design on my old N4
column72: I definitely regret it.  But for now
column74: even if there are occasional frustration points.  If you are an Android user
column75: please consider all these points and google similar stories before switching.Also
column76: I'm one of those workaholics and forever in search of super productivity
column77: hence my review that I'd like to go back to Android.  However
column78: I know plenty of people who swear by their iPhones for productivity.  If you are always connected and depend on a suite of iOS specific apps (including apps that are better designed or work better on iOS)
column79: then chances are you love the iPhone.  There are plenty of things to like and love about either OS.  It really does come down to personal preference.***UPDATE 2/9/15: I got to try the new Outlook 2015 app by Microsoft
column80: and it has alleviated a lot of the email/attachment issues that I have mentioned above.  It allows you to sign into your Exchange
column81: Outlook accounts as well as your Gmail
column83: and iCloud emails.  You can also integrate your OneDrive
column86: and that's where the magic begins.  Once integrated
column87: you can attach any file located in those drives
column88: which is great!  You can also attach files that are attached in emails that are already in your inbox!  And
column89: you can now reply an email with the option of attaching a file.  Finally
column90: you can decide if you want to open up links from emails in Safari or another browser installed on your phone (so
column91: you are no longer bound by default Apple apps).  This is a huge step forward
column92: and it's from Microsoft (a pleasant surprise).  ***This app has really improved my productivity needs
column93: since when considering the iPhone we have to take into account the hardware and the software/app ecosystem
column94: i think this makes sense to bump up the rating to 4/5.  There are still kinks when switching over if you are used to productive flexibility on Android phones
column95: but right now the 3rd party apps are getting better and better at work-arounds.

Title: Music lovers... what you need to know.
Author: Wayne
column5: the most critical feature that's amiss with iPhone is the quality of their music services.  This may sound astounding to you as it was to me but iTunes is one of the worst music software or general software application that exists.  Portable music devices is what really put Apple over the top the last decade.  So you'd imagine iTunes would just work like it's supposed to.  You'd be surprised how bad it is if you're switching over from Android music services such as Amazon Music.  I've had most of my music collection on Amazon Music.  Switching to Apple I thought it would be as easy as subscribing to iTunes Match and pushing my collection to iTunes cloud.  Not so simple.  Using iTunes on my pc it failed to recognize more than half of my mp3s.  Apparently
column6: this is a known issue with users complaining on the Apple support forums about how poor the matching software is.  It's slow when it works but most of the time it doesn't.  In comparison
column7: Amazon Music matching is a breeze.  the quality of the code is superior.  Now when you subscribe to iTunes Match you're supposed to get iTunes Radio without commercials.  All I ever got was commercials on the iPhone and iTunes on PC.  So this is a backend problem not necessarily tied to a device.  The iTunes interface on iPhone is just horrible.  The Music app to play your music is also horrible.  The user experience is lacking with little update or innovation over the last several years.The biggest problem with iTunes is that it's not an AppStore application but tightly integrated with iOS release.  I'd imagine iTunes upgrades and enhancements would be markedly improved if it was separated out as it's own App Store app.  There's little likelihood this will happen anytime soon
column8: however
column9: as there appears to be a monetary reason behind this intentional tightly coupled integration.  When you use apps like Shazaam or SoundHound and intend to purchase a track you can only do so thru iTunes.  That's also a drag.  You can't purchase from
column10: say
column11: Amazon Music (android users know you can purchase tracks from any music provider on the platform).  For apple to continue their music monopoly on IOS they have to package the music services as part of their platform
column12: that there are technical reasons why they can't open up their platform to 3rd party music purchasing services.  Therein lies their own demise of their music platform. There's little incentive to innovate.  What's odd even still is how anti-trust lawsuits haven't surfaced already.  If Microsoft can get slammed for shipping their own browser with their OS
column13: then how is it that Apple can go unscathed for purposely limiting customers freedom to choose their music provider?IOS is pretty good in general.  It's definitely better than Android or a linux hacked OS.  It's better quality software in general and I like the fact the hardware doesn't get hung up in some deadlock.  I can almost always escape some kind of software locking through the home button which seems to force a hardware interrupt.  It's a better system software for sure.  iTunes and it's supporting software
column14: however
column15: is pure crap.  Thumbs up if you think this review will help anyone else make their switch over from android.

Title: Four Stars
Author: Prakash wagley
Review: PositiveBest phone I have ever owned
column7: I went from a iPhone 4s to a galaxy s5 then to the iPhone 6 and it is by far the best phone I have ever had.  It is very fast and responsive.  The camera is excellent and does not have the delay that the s5 had.  The finger print scanner is excellent and a feature that is surprisingly useful.  You can unlock your iPhone with it or purchase stuff online with just your finger print.  I know the s5 also has one but it is years behind and can only be set up with one finger where the iPhone you can set multiple fingers which makes it nice if you switch hands while using the phone.  Also you have to swipe to unlock the S5 which can take multiple times to do where is the iPhone really takes more than a half second touch and unlock.  The battery life for me was about the same as on the s5 although I did like the power saving mode on the s5 which iPhone does not have.  The charging time on the iPhone seems to be about half the time it took to charge the galaxy S5 though so it's nice to know if you can plug it in for a few minutes you can charge about a percent per minute where the s5 was about 1% every two minutes. Another thing I prefer on the iOS system is Siri which is also years ahead of Google talk.  Much more useful
column8: understands me better
column9: many more functions and just much more refined.  If you're on the fence for a new phone the iPhone six will not disappoint you.

column11: iTunes still needs to be installed for them to work. If there is any bug or problem with iTunes
column12: then you can have problems. I could not get music on my PC to sync with the phone whether using iTunes or a 3rd party program. The transfer would just fail without any warning. After more than 20 minutes on phone with Apple tech
column13: who couldn't figure the problem out
column14: I was disconnected and never got a call back. Ended up trouble shooting the problem myself and discovered the trouble was from the iTunes installation being on a "locked drive". Google "repair security permissions for itunes for windows" for the solution.  If you don't have unlimited data
column15: and want to turn cellular data off
column16: you may find your bluetooth voice commands won't work.  You'll need to turn Siri off for them to work
column17: otherwise
column18: you'll have to listen to Siri telling you to connect to the internet.  If you're a fan of Apple and don't care about price
column19: or there is a business need to use Apple
column20: buy this phone. If you want value for your money
column21: have the freedom of choice
column22: and to optimize for your personal use
column23: then you have many more and better options elsewhere. A final word
column24: imo

column26: buy it direct from Apple.  I can verify that the no contract T-mobile iphone 6 they sell will work just fine with an AT&T sim card.

Title: Great Phone
Author: but needs work!
column5: I'll lead in to this letting everyone know I have a love/hate relationship with Apple being an Apple user since the early 90's. I have seen the things that have changed and the things that have stayed the same as Apple has moved from being a sinking dinghy to a thriving cruise line.I switched from Android to this iPhone
column6: but I have had quite a bit of experience with iPhones as my family has them
column7: I have a model for work
column8: etc. In general Android is far more flexible in allowing the user to create their own experience. It's like a car
column9: you pick the model with the factory and dealer installed options you want and then you can make your own changes. Apple limits the user modifications heavily (specifics below).I switched from Android because I was tired of all freezes
column10: pauses and crashes and all the iPhone reviews state the opposite. My hope is that I can live without the customization abilities to get a more stable and responsive solution. So far my experience is the iPhone is hands down the better hardware
column11: better hardware/software integrate and has far better performance and stability.For reference on performance and stability
column12: I have 154 apps installed
column13: am using 75.2GB of the storage
column14: 60.4 for purchased videos
column15: 3.7GB for Photos & Videos taken by the camera
column16: 1.7GB Music
column17: 2.7GB for Apple's productivity apps
column18: 182MB mail (8 mail accounts
column19: 3 are Exchange accounts)
column20: have custom mail signatures for all accounts
column21: custom notifications for everything including different notifications for each mail account
column22: use the Do Not Disturb feature option and have it enable automatically in the evening
column23: use the Control Center and Notification Center often
column24: have customized the Notification Center
column25: Wallpaper on the home and lock screens
column26: use WiFi
column28: use iCloud and Passbook/Apple Pay
column29: have many alarms
column30: etc. Point is with all this the iPhone is responsive and stable and with a few exceptions the iPhone version of apps have been better than their Android counterparts.Batter life seems better
column31: but comparing a Galaxy Note 2 (2 years old) with a current iPhone is not fair. As far as the other comparisons
column32: I know people who have Galaxy S5's
column33: Note 4's and other android phones and the performance and stability problems still exist which is backed by the reviews.I will say that the camera is not as amazing as indicated. I have had many issues with graininess and very slow focus. It's certainly hard to get a good picture quickly.I have been told that the iPhone is a more polished product and I would agree
column34: but I would say it's a very polished version 1.5 to 2.5 product. However
column35: some items are clearly further along because Apple has focused on those apps/features.The most glaring thing lacking customization in the iPhone
column36: the version 1.0 item
column37: is the clock. With everything that Apple does to make our lives easier
column38: they are glued to a 1970s/1980s electronic alarm clock paradigm.1) You have no control over snooze time and therefore
column39: there is no default setting that the user can change
column40: no per alarm snooze time option and no on the fly snooze time options.2) An alarm can be set for the next occurrence of the time you set or every x day
column41: but not this Friday just one time or for a specific date. You have to set your alarm the day before or if your future planning fits with the limited options
column42: you can plan your alarms ahead. So I'll create an alarm
column43: turn it off and then set a reminder to remind me to turn it on. That seems more complicated than it should be.3) Someone will say
column44: just replace the clock
column45: except only the Apple clock works with an option like Do Not Disturb on
column46: so if DND is on you have to leave a 3rd party clock app up on the screen
column48: for the alarms to work. I use DND because during sleep time I only want calls
column49: texts and alarms and I can click the silent switch to disable call and text sounds on the fly.The bottom line is that it is clear that Apple does not care about this app and there is not a good replacement option.Another glaring issue is iMessage and SMS. Why do I need to care if my contacts iPhone is connected in a way that allows special iMessage messages. If iMessage can't reach an SMS device via iMessage
column50: then it should automatically send the message as SMS. It should not take 10 minutes or hours or days or longer if ever for people to get a text. I can turn those features off
column51: but I lose functionality that does not require iMessage that Apple only provides for iMessage contacts. This is another immature thing. It's like a CD player made by a record label that only plays CDs produced by said label.This and the lack of being able to seamlessly use Google Voice are the only things that keep Android in my view. For reference
column52: in Android you can set your default app to use for everything including phone
column54: etc. So if I opened the main phone app
column55: typed in a number or selected from the address book
column56: when I clicked call it would call with my default which could be my Verizon number or my GV number or I could set it to ask me. So yes I can use GV on my iPhone
column57: but not with that level of convenience.The list below is not exhaustive
column58: but provides a good example of why I consider it version 1.5 to 2.5 software.1) Already covered alarm clock app
column59: iMessage and SMS and app integration like I described with Google Voice.2) No status indicator when in silent mode (switch on side of phone). Some have said just look at the switch. Well there are a number of reasons why that is not the best option for everyone. It's hard to see in the dark. If you have a case it's even harder to see. By that logic
column60: get rid of all status icons and you can go to the respective setting to see the status of that item. It's a simple status icon and there should be an option to show it.3) When selecting from the address book to add contacts to mail
column63: it would be awesome if you could select multiple. i.e. I may search for work contacts and want to select more than one rather than performing the same search over and over.4) Limited options when working with Bluetooth and WiFi connections. You can forget a device and with Bluetooth
column65: but you can't simply disconnect from a device or network and with bluetooth you can't limit what the device is used for. i.e. I may have a bluetooth earpiece for making calls
column66: but I may not want music to come through that device.With the disconnect sometimes it's convenient to disconnect without turning off the feature especially with bluetooth which should support multiple pairings. For WiFi
column67: I had an issue where it would not see other networks. Turning it off and on did not fix the issue. I had to forget the network that it was automatically attaching to and then I could see other networks. Having to forget a device or network should not be the solution. That should only have to be used if you want to forget the item or there is a problem with that specific item.5) For Do Not Disturb you have one auto option so you can have auto on/off on different days and when turning it on on the fly you have no option to turn it off after a period of time.6) The Command Center is nice
column68: but it leaves much to be desired. Being able to quickly turn items on and off is nice
column69: but what if you want to choose a specific WiFi network or Bluetooth device.How about being able to click and hold to select from a list of devices/networks with an option to open the WiFi/Bluetooth main settings?At the very least
column70: and this should be there even if the more specific options described above are provided
column71: a button to open settings.How about allowing an option to allow the Command Center to be accessed via the Notification Center (pulled from the top)?7) Changing settings can be a pain. I do like that there is a single place you can go for some settings such as notifications
column74: etc and a single place to quickly get to all app settings
column75: but that benefit should not remove the ability to get to all of these settings from within an app. It's the equivalent of adding steering wheel controls for the radio
column77: etc and removing the corresponding console controls.8) The mail app is nice
column78: but there are some issues.When adding a more complex (standard) signature with an image and hyperlinks
column79: the settings app crashes and it looses my images
column80: so a couple of emails have the image and then the image disappears.Not being able to set per folder "Mail Days to Sync" is a bummer. I have folders that I keep all important mail in that I need access to offline. I have other folders that have a lot of mail and I do not want all the messages in those folders to download when I do have to look at them on occasion. There needs to be more flexibility with this option.The options unread
column85: etc per mailbox would be nice.This is my review and I hope it helps you!

Title: great device - has some physical design issues

column5: coming from an iPhone 5.I'm an Apple enthusiast so this was an obvious choice for me.Overall

column10: however:1. The protruding rear camera lens is just stupid - so you really can't set the naked phone on its back without worrying about it.2. The rolled edges on the glass are just stupid - this means that a screen protector cannot go edge to edge.  It also means that most any case will have a gap between it and the glass at the eye of the case.3. Too thin - yes
column11: this phone is too thin - hence the protruding rear camera issue.  Thinness also contributes to making the phone very slippery and very easy to drop.  Maybe that is what Apple wants - drop the phone often so you have to replace it often?4. Confounding the thinness issue are the rounded edges.  Rounded edges make many cases very easy to slip off
column12: or at least not fit as snug as they otherwise could.5. Not case friendly:  Thin + round edge + rolled glass edges = a very unfriendly phone to accepting cases and screen protectors.  Overall
column13: I find the old iPhone 5/5s much easier to fit a case to it and install a screen protector.So
column14: the iPhone 6 is a very cool device. For everyday use like email and Internet
column15: I really do not notice any speed difference

Title: Both deisgn and quality of the iPhone have suffered significantly over the years (the quality of the glass is so poor it scratch
Author: typically lenient

Having it now for 2 months I would rename it iCrap6. Both deisgn and quality of the iPhone have suffered significantly over the years (the quality of the glass is so poor it scratches if you stare at it).  This convinced me not to upgrade the iPad so I installed iOS 8. Another mistake.  My old iPad has never worked so poorly.  As for moving to a Mac
column5: the idea has completely disappeared from my head. It seems the philosophy of Apple has also disappeared from the corporate psyche.

I searched around for a cheaper alternative when my son's phone dropped and shattered in the first week. The cheapest non-apple alternative I could find was $330 because the part alone is nearly $300. I was surprised that by merely falling out of a pocket the phone looked like it exploded. We've had iPhone 4

Title: Real value == $400
Author: Hil
Review: Quite a few people like to show off their iPhone 6 as a symbol of status. Apple has created such a brand with last year's technologies to lure people. While Samsung
column6: Motorola and other top Android manufacturers are pushing the limit of smart phone technologies
column7: Apple has lagged behind for 1 year on the hardware front and 2 years on the software front with Google. I wrote another review regarding the camera comparison between iPhone 6
column9: and LG G3. The photo samples are at https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B-mVIvj6SluAM0YzRGNZT0g5Snc&usp=sharing. While iPhone 6 and 6+'s camera has done better in the low light than LG G3
column10: iPhone 6's camera captured completely blurred license plate numbers compared to the other 2 phones. That was embarrassing losing so much details. Samsung Galaxy S5 might have a better chance winning the low light test with iPhone 6 but the mountain picture shows the lack of details on the trees from iPhone 6's camera compared to LG G3's. I was able to see the differences from the phones and have another hiker who owned iPhone 6+ to verify them. The differences are more obvious if viewed on PC with large monitors. Not everything is bad about the camera
column11: iPhone 6's camera actually did well capturing text in low light. Check the picture that has a yellow Chinese book. Zoom in and you'd see the text more clear than LG G3's. The file names tell you which picture belongs to which device. On the software side
column12: Apple finally allow accessing iCloud data via iCloud Drive following what Google did years back. So it's playing catchup. However
column13: my test of iCloud backup failed intermittently. Most of the iOS 8 features are following Google's Android 4.4 or barely matching it. Some people may think having a fingerprint sensor makes the device more secure. Definitely not. If fingerprint unlock fails
column14: it reverts to PIN unlock. Anyone who knows possible PIN numbers can unlock your iPhone 6 by bypassing the fingerprint unlock screen. I found this because the fingerprint unlock worked 45% of the time on me. What could be more embarrassing if you use Apple pay but fails. I will for sure be the customer in line next to the failed Apple pay user yelling "get out
column15: there are more people behind me trying to checkout". There are a few design decisions that make iOS 8 quite annoying. The most is mandatory password entry installing free apps. Android does not require that. One reason I can think of may be Apple does not want user to forget Apple ID's password. I've seen Android users fail to remember its Gmail password. Those dump ones are not using Google's string service back end and are usually the victims of converting to buying iPhones. The other less annoying design decision is that it requires user touching OK for "[App] would like to access your [location/photo/etc…]". I had to touch OK at every prompt. I can't think of practical uses of not allowing the app to do its functionality. If you don't trust the app
column16: maybe you should not have downloaded it. I've seen a user choosing not allow for Google search/maps resulting in find a Starbucks 1000 miles away (useless search result). The user was misled that someone was trying to snoop on her. Android takes a different approach showing users the access permissions at app download time. Which eliminates the needs to asking users for permission at each turn. I believe the true price for iPhone 6 should be $400
column17: not $650. The screen to body ratio is another sign of inferior hardware engineering. The top part of the phone from the edge of the screen to the top end measured in length is wider than LG G3. Such length is even wide on iPhone 6+. Apple should have pushed the screen edge to the top end  of the phone. Such tiny space could only allow putting a speaker and a front camera. LG G2
column18: G3 did it. But Apple failed. Remember Apple bought the IPS LCD screen from LG and have Foxconn assemble it. The pixel resolution for iPhone 6 is 720p
column20: LG G3: 1440p

Title: Apple fans
Author: try a different phone and see what you are missing
column5: I'll never buy another iPhone until Apple adds a "BACK" button.I've owned iPhones and Android phones. While a lot can be said of the nice features of iPhone
column6: the lack of a "Back" button shows how stupidly arrogant Apple is and how it's sacrificing user experience for its bloated ego. Android and Windows mobile operating systems both have the "Back" button for a reason - the Back button is the easiest
column7: most often used and most natural way to navigate in almost all apps. Apply doesn't add this function for no other reason than it doesn't want to admit it needs to learn a thing or two from others. There is Back button in iPhone Safari browser and some other apps
column8: but each app may have this function at a different location
column9: so users have to look for it each time. A Back button built into the operating system as in Android and Windows is obviously more convenient and natural. But Apple's ego is too large to go "Back" to fix this issue. Again
column10: that's STUPIDLY arrogant. I'll never buy another Apply product until it learns a little modesty and make its product better for customers
column11: not its ego!- Update in response to a comment from another user on my reviewThe user (obviously an Apple fan) said that all iPhone apps have some sort of "Back" function tied to the iOS navigation requirement. But that's exactly the problem. Each app builds the "Back" function differently
column12: and the location varies from app to app. In Android and Windows
column13: the Back button is always conveniently at the bottom of the phone
column14: so one-hand operation is easy and natural. But on iPhone
column15: even before the larger iPhone 6
column16: it's almost impossible to easily navigate with one hand. And one simple touch to go "Back" in Android and Windows usually requires two or more moves. The really sad thing about iPhone is a commercial product turned into a religion. Apple fans blindly follow it without any rational thinking. I'm definitely not saying Android is perfect
column17: but if Apple can't add a convenient
column18: natural navigation function (which is obviously easy for it to do)
column19: it says something about its mentality. Apple fans may feel proud of all the tricks in navigating iPhone
column20: but isn't iOS supposed to be the most intuitive and simple to use? Think of another difference between iPhone and Android phones. In Android
column21: users can either set display brightness to "auto"
column22: or manually adjust it. In iPhone
column23: iOS automatically adjusts the brightness
column24: users have no choice. Apple fans would say iOS makes it simple so users don't need to adjust it. Android also has the default "auto" feature so users don't need to adjust it. But the difference is Android gives users the choice just in case users need to. And you know what? The universe has so many possibilities that some time the auto brightness doesn't fit a particular situation! Apple regards itself to be the master of the universe
column25: while Android and Windows know there are limitations to whatever geniuses can foresee.All I'm trying to say is
column26: if you love iPhone

Title: iPhone 6 is The Best iPhone Apple Have Ever Released
Author: James Thomas
Review: So let’s get down to what matters right? Specs
column5: specs and more specs! Plus what’s new and why we should even think about upgrading from our iPhone 5s.1: Size: The dimensions and weight of course matter; unless you don’t mind carrying around a brick the size of trailer. The iPhone 6 comes in at 5.44 x 2.64 x 0.27 inches & weighing in at 4.55 oz. which of course is a bit larger than my 5s. This should help out some of us with slightly larger hands
column6: but still have a nice grip and feel for all around daily use
column7: ease of navigation and just general accessibility.2: RETINA HD DISPLAY: Having shatter proof glass is definitely necessary
column8: unless you plan on keeping your iPhone 6 in the retail box- never holding it and making phone calls on speaker phone for the rest of your life. Yes

column10: you better know the screen is delivering higher contrast and way better color accuracy
column11: which all plays out as just an all around incredible display. Not to mention a bigger screen at 4.7’’ vs my iPhone 5’s 4.0’’ and higher resolution compared to the 5s
column12: with the 750 x1334 (750p resolution) and a 1400 contrast ratio. Another added feature that is pretty slick is the dual-domain pixels for wider viewing angles
column13: so when I’m showing my friend something
column14: I don’t have to have to reach out and aim my phone directly in front of their face.3: NFC support: Now apparently we will only be able to use NFC capabilities with Apple pay for now
column15: which allows me to make touch-less payments in stores and stuff
column16: which I think is incredibly cool and futuristic. Now I know some will complain as to why all the capabilities aren’t functional
column17: and no one truly knows except for Apple
column18: but apparently the particular NFC chip has more capabilities beyond just Apple Pay. Apparently at an Apple event
column19: the watch unlocked a hotel room
column20: so I guess these are just some of the possibilities that this particular NFC chipset holds. So even though I have to wait a bit to use the NFC fully
column21: I’m sure the wait will be well worth it in the long run.4: Speed: Using the Apple A8 chipset and a Dual Core 1.4 GHz Cyclone
column22: compared to the iPhone 5’s 1.3 Ghz

column24: working
column25: gaming
column26: and texting and have 100 apps open at the same time
